content: The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to prescribe rules and regulations under Section 7254 of title 38, United States Code. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for the recall of retired judges. The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to recall retired judges for further service in accordance with Section 7257 of title 38, United States Code. Retired judges must provide notice of availability and willingness to be recalled for service on the Court. The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to recall retired judges who have provided notice of availability and willingness to be recalled for further service. Recall-eligible retired judges can be recalled by the chief judge in accordance with the Act. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows the chief judge to recall a recall-eligible retired judge for up to 90 days per calendar year, with a total limit of 180 days, upon certification of substantial service need. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows the chief judge to recall a recall-eligible retired judge for up to 90 days per calendar year, with a total limit of 180 days. If the retired judge declines to perform the service, they will be removed from the recall-eligible status. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows the chief judge to recall a recall-eligible retired judge for up to 90 days per calendar year, with a total limit of 180 days. If the retired judge declines to perform the service or becomes permanently disabled, they will be removed from the recall-eligible status. A recalled retired judge can exercise all powers and duties of an active judge. A recall-eligible retired judge can be recalled to serve for up to 90 days per year, with a total limit of 180 days, under the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999. The recalled judge can exercise all powers and duties of an active judge, with specified pay rates based on retirement status. A recall-eligible retired judge can be recalled to serve for up to 90 days per year, with a total limit of 180 days, under the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999. The recalled judge can exercise all powers and duties of an active judge, with specified pay rates based on retirement status. Additionally, a judge recalled under this section who retired under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5 shall be considered a reemployed annuitant under that chapter. SEC. 4 amends Section 7296(b) of title 38, United States Code, to only credit years of service as a judge of the Court for calculating an individual's service. Fractional parts of a year less than 183 days are disregarded, while 183 days or more are credited as a full year. SEC. 5 addresses judges' retired pay. The retired pay of a recall-eligible retired judge under section 7257 of title 38, United States Code, shall be the pay of a judge of the court. The retired pay of a judge of the court (or chief judge) upon retirement is determined based on their status at the time of retirement. If a judge did not provide notice of availability for service in a recalled status, their retired pay will be the rate applicable at retirement. If a judge was recall-eligible but removed from recall status, their retired pay will be based on their pay at retirement. The retired pay of a judge is determined based on their status at retirement. If removed from recall status, their pay will be based on the rate at retirement. Cost-of-living adjustments apply only to retired pay computed under specific circumstances. Cost-of-living adjustments for retired judges are limited to prevent their pay from exceeding the annual rate of pay for the chief judge of the court. Adjustments can only be made to ensure the retired judge's pay is equal to the annual rate of pay in effect at the time of adjustment. Cost-of-living adjustments for retired judges are limited to prevent their pay from exceeding the annual rate of pay for the chief judge of the court. Adjustments can only be made to ensure the retired judge's pay is equal to the annual rate of pay in effect at the time of adjustment. Coordination with military retired pay is also addressed in the amendments. The amendment addresses the coordination of military retired pay for uniformed service members who become judges of the court. Retired or retainer pay is suspended during active service on the court but resumes without reduction upon retirement as a judge. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON ACTIVITIES OF RETIRED JUDGES. Section 7299 of title 38, United States Code, limits the activities of retired judges from the Court in practicing law by representing clients in veterans' benefits claims against the United States or its agencies. Retired judges forfeit their retired pay for a year if they engage in such representation. Section 7299 of title 38, United States Code, restricts retired judges from representing clients in veterans' benefits claims against the United States or its agencies. Retired judges lose their retired pay for a year if they engage in such representation. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. SEC. 7. Early retirement authority for current judges to stagger terms. Retirement Authorized: One eligible judge per year from 1999 to 2003 can retire if they meet specific criteria, including having at least 10 years of service and being at least 55 years old. An eligible judge can retire if they meet specific criteria, including having at least 20 years of service, being at least 55 years old, and providing notice in accordance with the rules. If multiple judges are eligible in a year, the one with the most seniority will be allowed to retire. An eligible judge must provide written notice to retire by April 1 of the year, except for 1999 where the deadline is November 1 or 15 days after the enactment of the Act. The retirement date must be specified and the notice is irrevocable. The retirement date for a judge eligible to retire must be specified in written notice, which is irrevocable. The retirement must occur during the fiscal year in which notice is given, not earlier than 90 days after the notice, except for judges retiring in 1999 who must retire between 90 and 120 days after notice is given. In 1999, judges must retire between 90 and 120 days after notice is given. Retired judges are considered under section 7296(b)(1) of title 38, United States Code. The rate of retired pay is determined by section 7296(c)(1) of title 38, United States Code. The rate of retired pay for judges is determined by multiplying the rate applicable under section 7296(c)(1) of title 38, United States Code by a fraction based on years of service and age. Adjustments in retired pay for judges available for recall are subject to section 7296(f)(3)(B) of title 38, United States Code. Adjustments in retired pay for judges available for recall are subject to section 7296(f)(3)(B) of title 38, United States Code. An adjustment in annuities under civil service retirement laws also applies to retired pay for recall-eligible retired judges under section 7257 of title 38, or those removed from recall status due to disability. The duty of the actuary is amended under section 7298(e)(2) of title 38, United States Code. The duty of the actuary under section 7298(e)(2) of title 38, United States Code is amended to include a value determined by an actuary with respect to a payment that may be made under subsection (b) from the retirement fund within the contemplation of law.
